entry.title: Evaluation of the Cycling City and Towns Programme
entry.content:
Introduction

A consortium led by AECOM working with the University of the West of England and The Tavistock Institute is undertaking an independent evaluation of the Cycling City and Towns (CCT) programme. They are working with Sustrans (who are leading a programme of monitoring activity) to measure the extent to which the anticipated outcomes and wider impacts have been generated by the CCT programme and to measure its efficiency, effectiveness and value for money.

Reports

An interim report has been published which provides a summary of the initial emerging evidence from the evaluation of the CCT programme.

  • Evaluation of the Cycling City and Towns Programme interim report, 19 January 2011

Also available to download are complete baseline survey datasets and tables.

  • Evaluation of the cycling city and towns programme: baseline data

Analysis of the baseline survey data has been undertaken to investigate the potential health benefits of increasing cycling in the CCTs.

  • Investigating the potential health benefits of increasing cycling in the Cycling City and Towns, 24 April 2012

In-depth qualitative research with residents was undertaken during 2010, to explore how residents in the CCTs responded to the cycling investment.

  • Qualitative research with residents, 15 August 2012

Background to the Cycling City and Towns Programme

Between April 2008 and March 2011, the Department for Transport, the Department of Health and Cycling England invested over £140m to promote cycling and to address a historic decline in cycling activity. Part of this investment (around £50m) was used to create one Cycling City and eleven Cycling Towns (CCTs). Alongside matched funding from the participating local authorities, the investment aimed to deliver a step change in the provision of facilities and the promotion of cycling for travel and leisure purposes, leading to wider impacts in areas such as health, decongestion, reduced carbon emissions and accessibility.

The programme built on the experience of the six original Cycling Demonstration Towns (CDTs), which began receiving increased levels of funding in 2005, and which reported interim evaluation results in 2009.

  • Analysis and synthesis of evidence on the effects of investment in six Cycling Demonstration Towns, 9 November 2009
  • Cycling Demonstration Towns: results from the first three years

Evaluation Approach

The aims of the evaluation are to:

  • measure the extent to which the anticipated outcomes and wider impacts have been achieved through the CCT programme and to assess whether it has provided value for money
  • assess the effectiveness of interventions, including those targeted towards specific population groups and journeys
  • understand the factors which drive local travel behaviours and how these can be influenced to encourage cycling behaviours
  • explore the approaches which have been critical to the success of the programme
  • generate evidence of good practice which can be used to inform the design and delivery of future local initiatives aimed at encouraging cycling

The evaluation approach has been informed by the evaluation framework developed to assess the impacts of small-scale, low-cost transport schemes which make ‘better use’ of the existing network.

  • Evaluating transport schemes which make better use of the existing network

The evaluation uses a ‘Theory of Change’ approach which assesses the implementation of the programme from its rationale to its inputs and outputs, to test whether the programme has caused the intended and unintended outcomes and wider impacts.

  • Guidance for transport impact evaluations (section 6.2), 17 March 2010

This approach has guided the development of data collection activities, which include:

  • large-scale pre-and post-intervention surveys of households in CCT programme areas
  • qualitative interviews and accompanied cycle journeys with residents in each CCT
  • interviews with local delivery teams and local and national stakeholders, and
  • monitoring trends in cycling activity

  • publishing schedule: annually, July each year

Latest data

  • of all urban trips under 5 miles taken in England in 2010 35% were by walking or cycling and 10% were by public transport modes.
  • the region with the highest proportion of urban trips less than 5 miles taken by walking or cycling was London with 39% in 2010
  • the lowest proportion was in the West Midlands - 34%.

The proportion of walking/cycling and public transport trips are calculated using the total trips by main mode reported in the National Travel Survey by residents living in urban areas. entry.title: RTFO guidance
entry.content:
The guidance

The Renewable Transport Fuel Obligation (RTFO) guidance provides support for fuel suppliers, independent verifiers and others involved in the supply of biofuels for use in road transport in the UK.

The guidance is divided into three parts.

Part 1: process guidance

This provides information on how fossil fuel and renewable transport fuel suppliers should comply with the RTFO Order and practical instruction on how they should submit the required information to the administrator. It provides detailed instructions and information on:

  • the obligation that the RTFO Order puts on certain fuel suppliers
  • applying for and maintaining an account with the RTFO Administrator
  • applying for Renewable Transport Fuels Certificates (RTFCs)
  • penalties for non-compliance

Part 2: carbon & sustainability guidance

This aims to provide assistance on carbon and sustainability (C&S) reporting for fossil fuel and renewable transport fuel suppliers that wish to benefit from receiving Renewable Transport Fuel Certificates (RTFCs) under the Renewable Transport Fuel Obligation (RTFO). It clarifies sustainability criteria for biofuels supplied under the RTFO and how to demonstrate compliance. It provides detailed information on:

  • reporting carbon and sustainability data
  • demonstrating compliance with greenhouse gas and land use criteria
  • mass balance rules
  • wastes and residues

Part 3: guidance for verifiers

All carbon and sustainability data associated with biofuels must be verified by an independent third party before Renewable Transport Fuel Certificates will be awarded for those fuels. The guidance for verifiers outlines the approach to this process.
It includes detailed information on:

  • the purpose and requirements of verification
  • planning and risk assessment
  • developing an assurance strategy
  • reporting and assurance statements

Key changes

The publication of this guidance follows the implementation of the transport elements of the Renewable Energy Directive (RED) on December 15 2011 and therefore includes a number of significant differences to those versions published prior to that date. These include guidance on:

  • the introduction of mandatory sustainability criteria for biofuels, including a minimum GHG saving
  • double rewards to incentivise certain types of biofuels, such as those made from wastes
  • a requirement for suppliers to have carbon and sustainability data for their fuels independently verified before Renewable Transport Fuel Certificates are awarded

Supplementary guidance for small suppliers of used cooking oil biodiesel

This supplementary guidance is primarily intended for use by smaller suppliers of biofuels who have previously not had to verify the carbon sustainability (C&S) of the data associated with their biofuel. This verification process is now a requirement in the Renewable Energy Directive (RED). It should be noted however, that this guidance is not intended to replace the full RTFO guidance (parts 1-3) but to provide an overview of the requirements under the new scheme, particularly for those suppliers who are unfamiliar with the new requirements.

entry.title: Department for Transport privacy policy
entry.content:
This policy:

  • explains the privacy policy for the Department for Transport and its agencies, and explains how we will use and protect any information we collect about you when you visit this website and other websites that we manage
  • provides fuller information about the personal data that is collected by the department’s agencies as part of their business operations

The department has published an information charter on this website, which sets out the standards you can expect from us when we handle your personal information. It also explains how you can ask to see a copy of any personal information that we are processing about you.

  • DfT information charter

Whilst the Department for Transport is a single data controller for the purposes of the Data Protection Act 1998, each of our agencies has separate arrangements in place for managing compliance with that Act. The information charter will tell you who to contact if you have any concerns about the way any part of the department is processing your personal data.

Information collected from our website

This website will not capture or store your personal information without your knowledge, other than to log your IP address and session information (which includes the duration of your visit to our site and the type of web browser used). We may use this data in aggregate form to help us improve the operation and appeal of our site.

Where you are asked to provide information about yourself when you visit certain parts of our site, we will make clear what we want to use that information for. We will keep the information for the length of time needed to provide the service or information you have requested, or in accordance with the law or government policy.

entry.title: Rail interoperability TSI FAQ
entry.content:
Detailed guidance on the application of TSIs and the implementation of interoperability

If you are still unable to find an answer to your query, please email us at interoperability@dft.gsi.gov.uk.

  • What is a TSI?
  • What is the role of TSIs?
  • What is a status of TSIs?
  • How are TSIs developed?
  • What do TSIs contain?
  • What are ‘Specific Cases’?
  • How are errors in TSIs dealt with?

What is a TSI?

A TSI is a common, harmonised, technical standard required to satisfy the essential requirements of interoperability which include safety, reliability and availability, health, environmental protection and technical compatibility.

Depending on their scope, TSIs may also contain other specific requirements relating to either ‘structural’ subsystems (such as infrastructure, rolling stock, energy, and control/command and signalling) or ‘functional’ subsystems (such as maintenance, traffic operation and management and telematics applications for passengers and freight services).

TSIs are prepared by the European Railway Agency (‘ERA’) under a mandate from the European Commission. The mandate specifies the format which TSIs must conform to and the method that ERA must use to prepare them.

What is the role of TSIs

A Contracting Entity, which has responsibility for the management of any project, must ensure that the essential requirements of safety, reliability and availability, health, environmental protection and technical compatibility are met. The application of TSIs removes the need for individual Contracting Entities to decide how the essential requirements should be met since they set out the means whereby, for the specific situations within their scope, these will be met. TSIs also drive standardisation by mandating interfaces and assessment methodologies.

The TSI framework is supplemented by NNTRs which, in respect of open (unresolved) points in the TSI, fulfill the role of defining how the essential requirements will be met.

What is the status of TSIs?

TSIs are ‘Decisions’ under European Community law and have effect as if they were domestic regulations (secondary legislation). As such they are binding on Member States, and because the Railways (Interoperability) Regulations 2011 make specific reference to TSIs and apply them for domestic purposes, their requirements are binding on the rail industry in the United Kingdom.

How are TSIs developed?

TSIs are prepared by the European Railway Agency (‘ERA’) under a mandate from the European Commission. The mandate specifies the format of the TSI and the method that the ERA must use to prepare it.

Once a work programme is agreed, ERA establishes Drafting Group on which each National Safety Authority has a seat as well as experts from a number of relevant European Railway organisations. The Group must prepare a document that matches the standard framework and content of a TSI.

Once the Drafting Group has completed its task, ERA sends the final draft to the European Commission, for consideration, amendment, and acceptance by the Railway Interoperability and Safety Committee (‘RISC’). Once ratified by a vote at RISC, and following subsequent approval by the Council and Parliament of the European Union, the European Commission issues the TSI as a Decision which then becomes binding upon Member States.

This process normally takes around three years and the Rail Safety and Standards Board has published Guidance on TSI Development and an associated Checklist.

What do TSIs contain?

The structure and content of a TSI is prescribed in the Interoperability Directives and can be summarised as:

Chapter 2 - establishes its scope;

Chapter 3 - specifies the essential requirements for the relevant subsystem;

Chapter 4 - lists the basic parameters of the subsystem necessary to meet the essential requirements and its interfaces with other subsystems. It also specifies the functional and technical specifications which must be met and its interfaces to achieve specified performance;

Chapter 5 - determines the Interoperability Constituents and their interfaces necessary to achieve interoperability;

Chapter 6 - describes the procedures for assessing the conformity or suitability for use of Interoperability Constituents and for performing the EC Verification of the subsystem; and

Chapter 7 - describes the implementing provisions in certain specific cases, including recommendations regarding the time objectives for the transition from the existing to the final situation where there is full compliance with the TSIs (referred to as either an implementation plan or strategy). This chapter frequently contains the answers sought by Contracting Entities and Notified Bodies to difficult compliance questions.

What are ‘Specific Cases’?

Specific cases are provisions made in TSIs to deal with particular circumstances prevailing in a particular Member State. For example, Great Britain has specific cases in the Infrastructure and Rolling Stock TSIs in relation to the structure gauge because our infrastructure is different to that found in mainland Europe.

Specific cases for all Member States are included in Chapter 7 of each TSI.

How are errors in TSIs dealt with?

Errors in TSIs may be either ‘critical’ or ‘minor’ in scope.

An error in a TSI is critical if it:

  • prevents the completion of subsystem or interoperable constituent design
  • prevents the conformity assessment of the subsystem or the interoperable constituent
  • prevents the placing into service of the subsystem or the placing onto the market of the interoperable constituent
  • prevents the interoperability of the subsystem or the interoperable constituent
  • contributes to unsafe operation not foreseen as part of the certification of the subsystem and / or the interoperable constituent or
  • contributes directly to an accident or incident

The European Commission has put in place a formal and ‘rapid’ procedure for resolving critical errors. If you think that your difficulties arise from one of the scenarios described, please email us at interoperability@dft.gsi.gov.uk to explore whether this is the best route to pursue.

Where the error has arisen because a specification is impossible to apply in one Member State or in one specified (but generic) situation, then the European Commission can be petitioned for a Specific Case to be made and included in the TSI. This is likely to be the device that is used to deal with some of the critical errors.

Non-critical errors

Other errors are regarded as minor errors, and it is the Department’s responsibility to resolve non-critical errors once they are brought to its attention. As with critical errors, please email interoperability@dft.gsi.gov.uk to discuss the problem.

Minor errors are regarded as less urgent than critical errors and will be addressed in the routine review of the TSI.

The Rail Safety and Standards Board has established a log to capture information relating to problems which have been encountered during the application of TSIs in the United Kingdom at www.rssb.co.uk/EUROPE/Pages/TSI.aspx.
